metadata.title: VPS29 exerts opposing effects on endocytic viral entry

body_text.text: confirmed knock-out (KO), both by sequencing target loci and by western blot analyses ( Figure  134 S1A). Importantly, KO of these genes did not affect cellular viability or proliferation. Because 135 viral dependency factors identified via CRISPR screening might be required in a cell-type 136 specific manner, we evaluated the requirement of these genes for infection in multiple cell lines 137 expressing ACE2 (the receptor for both SARS-CoV-2 and HCoV-NL63): A549-ACE2, HT1080-138 ACE2, and 293T-ACE2. 139 140
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Given their function in endosomal trafficking, we hypothesized that these hits would most likely 141 affect viral entry. We therefore performed single-cycle infection assays and quantified infected 142 cells via flow cytometry. There was strong requirement for VPS29/CCC complex as well as 143 WDR81/91 in A549 cells for all CoVs tested (Figure 2A-D) . However, the was no requirement 144 these factors in for IAV, adenovirus, or RSV infection of A549 cells ( Figure 2E -G). In all other 145 cell lines tested, there was a strong requirement for VPS29 for all coronaviruses but no 146 dependency on VPS29 or the other candidate proteins was found for adenovirus and RSV 147
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: ( Figure We found that VSV infection was unaffected by VPS29 KO ( Figure 2U ). Because the sole 158 difference between rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 and VSV itself is that rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 enters cells 159
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: using the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in lieu of VSV-G, these data suggest that it is the entry 160 pathway that imposes the requirement for VPS29. Given the strong requirement for VPS29 by all 161
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: tested HCoVs, in all cell lines tested, we sought to further confirm the relevance of VPS29 to 162
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: HCoV infection. To do so, we used CRISPR/Cas9 to KO VPS29 in normal human bronchial 163 epithelial (NHBE) primary lung cells. Loss of VPS29 strongly inhibited HCoV-OC43 infection 164
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: in NHBE cells ( Figure 2V ), suggesting that VPS29 is important for HCoV infection of 165 physiologically relevant cells. 166 167
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In contrast to effects on coronavirus infection, we observed precisely the opposite effect of 168 VPS29 or CCC complex deficiency on IAV infection in HT1080-ACE2 and 293T-ACE2 cells. 169 That is, KO of VPS29 or CCC complex components enhanced IAV infection ( Figure 2M ,S) 170 while WDR81/91 KO had no effect. To confirm the phenotype observed using the IAV strain 171
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A/WSN/33, we analyzed two separate strains of 2009 pandemic H1N1 IAV; 172
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A/Netherlands/602/2009 (H1N1)pdm09 (H1N12009 Netherlands) and A/California/04/2009 173 (H1N1)pdm09 (H1N12009 California). We found that the ability of VPS29 KO to enhance IAV entry 174 was conserved in the pandemic IAV strains ( Figure 2W ,X). That the same set of endocytic 175
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: factors could promote infection of coronaviruses while antagonizing IAV infection indicates 176
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: endosome-based viral entry pathways are influenced by specific sets of host proteins that can 177 facilitate or restrict viral entry. 178 179 HCoV-229E, and rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 infection ( Figure 3A -D). These data strongly suggest that 189 the participation of VPS29 in the Retromer complex (VPS26A/VPS29/VPS35), which is 190 recruited to endosomes via Rab7A, is the means by which it facilitates CoV infection (Rojas et 191 al., 2008 Figure 4A ,B and S2). Importantly, there was a return to normal 236 endosome phenotype after reconstitution with wildtype VPS29, confirming that this effect is due 237
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: to VPS29 KO ( Figure 4C and S2). The appearance of enlarged, deacidified vesicles was 238 maintained in VPS29 KO cells reconstituted with VPS29I91D or VPS29L152E ( Figure 4D ,E and 239 S2), suggesting that this phenotype is due to retromer disfunction. Quantification of the pH-240
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: sensitive Dextran signal from these images revealed a 3.7-fold decrease in fluorescence intensity 241 in VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 4F ) that is rescued upon reconstitution with WT VPS29, but not with 242 VPS29I91D or VPS29L152E. Importantly, the enlarged endosomes in VPS29 KO cells exhibited 243 equivalent fluorescent intensity to endosomes in normal cells when cells were incubated with 244 pH-insensitive AF-488 Dextran, indicating that while they were deacidified, they were not 245 impaired in cargo loading ( Figure 5A , B and S3). 246 247 VPS29 KO results in entrapment of rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 in endosomes 248
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: Given the above findings, we hypothesized that CoV infection is impaired in VPS29 KO cells 249 due to impediment in spike dependent egress from endosomes. To test this idea, we generated 250 rVSV/SARS-CoV-2NG-P, a replication-competent chimeric VSV expressing SARS-CoV-2 Spike 251 protein in lieu of VSV-G, and containing the VSV structural protein P fused to mNeonGreen 252 (NG-P), thus enabling the direct observation of entering viral particles (Schott et al., 2005) . 253 254
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: At 60 minutes post infection of parental HT1080 cells few NG-P punctae were evident within 255 2xFYVE-mSCAR labeled endosomes, suggesting successful egress of most rVSV/SARS-CoV-256 2NG-P particles ( Figure 6A and S4A) and minimal accumulation therein. However, in VPS29 KO 257 cells, enlarged endosomes contained many rVSV/SARS-CoV-2NG-P punctae at 60 min after 258 infection. Likewise, when cells were infected in the presence of labeled Dextran and imaged 60 259 minutes post infection, we observed a similar phenotype with rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 particles 260 accumulated in enlarged, Dextran-containing vesicles in VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 6B and S4B). 261
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: Overall, these data indicate that the major inhibitory effect of VPS29 KO on CoV infection is the 262 result of failed egress from endosomes. 263 264
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: Similar experiments in which incoming IAV virions were detected by immunofluorescence 60 265 min after ( Figure 6C and S5) revealed that IAV particles did not accumulate in the enlarged 266 2xFYVE-mSCAR labeled endosomes in VPS29 KO cells. Thus, the effect of VPS29 KO on 267 rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 was indeed specific. In fact, there was significantly greater association 268 between incoming IAV and 2xFYVE-labeled endosomes in parental HT1080 cells as compared 269 to VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 6C and S5), mirroring the opposing effects of VPS KO on HCoV and 270 IAV infection. 271 272 We hypothesized that such effect might be due to VPS29-dependent trafficking of antiviral 273 proteins with activity against IAV to endosomes, such as IFITM3. We observed that IFITM3 274 knockdown enhanced IAV infection of parental HT1080 cells ( Figure S6A ), in agreement with 275 previous reports (Feeley et al., 2011) . However, IFITM3 knockdown augmented IAV infection 276 in VPS29 KO cells ( Figure S6A ), suggesting that the enhancement of IAV infection in VPS29 277
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: KO cells was not the result of loss of IFITM3 activity. Concordantly, IFITM3 localized to 278 2xFYVE-labeled endosomes in both WT and VPS29 KO cells, and there was no clear difference 279
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: in localization ( Figure S6B ). Overall. these finding suggest that enhanced IAV infection in 280
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: VPS29 KO cells is due to increased egress from endosomes but is not due to altered localization 281 and/or impaired activity of IFITM3. 282 283
body_text.section: VPS29-associated proteins facilitate CoV infection and hinder IAV infection

body_text.text: cathepsin activity 285
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: The aforementioned findings indicate that the reduced susceptibility to HCoV infection in 286
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: VPS29 KO cells is spike-specific and is the consequence of failed egress from endosomes. We 287
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: hypothesized that this effect could be due to impaired spike processing by endosomal proteases 288 during entry. We used HIV-1-based pseudotyped viruses to test the susceptibility of various CoV 289 spikes to VPS29 KO and cathepsin inhibition using the drug E64d. As rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 bears 290 a point mutation, R683G, which ablates the polybasic furin cleavage site, we tested pseudotypes 291
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: bearing WT or R683G mutant spike proteins, as well as spike proteins from SARS-CoV and 292 SARS-like CoV from bats and pangolins, which also do not contain polybasic cleavage sites 293 (Coutard et al., 2020) . 294 295
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: Pseudotypes bearing both the WT and R683G mutant SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins were sensitive 296 to VPS29 KO and cathepsin inhibition. However, cathepsin inhibition did not further decrease 297 infection of VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 7A ). The SARS-CoV-2R683G (Figure7B), SARS-CoV 298 (Figure7C), and the SARS-like bat ( Figure 7D ) and pangolin viruses ( Figure 7E ,F) that lack furin 299 cleavage sites were more impacted by VPS29 KO and cathepsin inhibition than WT SARS-CoV-300 2. Indeed, in several instances, VPS29 KO and/or cathepsin inhibition resulted in undetectable 301 infection by SARS-CoV-2R683G, SARS-CoV, and the SARS-like bat/pangolin CoVs. Similarly, 302
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: infectivity assays utilizing rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 also revealed a dose-dependent inhibition of 303 infectivity upon cathepsin inhibition in parental HT1080, but no impairment of infection upon 304 cathepsin inhibition in VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 7G ). 305 306
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: That there was no further effect of cathepsin inhibition on CoV infection in VPS29 KO cells 307
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: suggests that the effect of these two manipulations converge on a common pathway in promoting 308 egress from endosomes. We thus hypothesized that VPS29 KO impedes CoV infection by 309
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: impairing proper processing of spike by cathepsins. If this were indeed the case, then VPS29 KO 310 should impair infection mediated by ebolavirus (EBOV) glycoprotein (GP), which is known to 311 require processing by endosomal cathepsins (Schornberg et al., 2006) . To test this, we performed 312 infectivity assays in WT and VPS29 KO cells using a recombinant VSV expressing EBOV GP in 313 lieu of VSV-G (rVSV/EBOV-GP) (Mulherkar et al., 2011) . Indeed, we observed a strong 314 inhibition of rVSV/EBOV-GP with both cathepsin inhibition and loss of VPS29 ( Figure 7H ). 315
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: This result suggests that the susceptibility of VPS29 KO is mediated by impaired cathepsin 316 activity. 317 318
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: Consistent with the above conclusion, when parental HT1080 cells were treated with the 319 cathepsin inhibitor E64d, infected with rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 NG-P and examined microscopically, 320
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: we observed a phenotype similar to that seen in VPS29 KO cells (see Figure 6A ). Specifically, 321
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: substantially more rVSV/SARS-CoV-2NG-P punctae were evident within endosomes, and the 322 endosomes appear enlarged with similar appearance and morphology to those observed in 323 VPS29 KO cells ( Figure 7I and S7). To directly test whether VPS29 KO results in impaired 324 endosomal cathepsin activity, we measured endosomal cathepsin activity in WT and VPS29 KO 325
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: HT1080 cells using a substrate that generates a fluorescent signal upon cleavage by cathepsin L. 326
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: Indeed, in WT cells, we observed a strong red fluorescence signal in vesicular structures, 327
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: indicating high levels of cathepsin activity. However, in VPS29 KO cells the red fluorescence 328 signal was nearly absent, indicative of impaired cathepsin activity in VPS29 KO cells ( Figure  329 7J). To determine if the loss of cathepsin L activity was the result of failed trafficking of 330 cathepsins to the endolysosomal system, we performed immunofluorescence studies utilizing 331 tagged cathepsin L in cells with endosomes labeled with 2xFYVE-mSCAR. There was no 332 change in cathepsin L localization to 2xFYVE-mSCAR-positive endosomes in VPS29 KO cells 333
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: ( Figure 7K ). These data suggest that the loss of cathepsin activity in VPS29 KO cells is not a 334 result of impaired trafficking of cathepsin itself to endosomes, but rather change endosomal 335 conditions in VPS29 KO cells, such as increased pH, reduces cathepsin activity therein. 336 337 DISCUSSION 338
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: While the advent of robust, high-throughput screening modalities has generated a wealth of 339 information regarding host-viral interactions, the underlying mechanism of action for many host 340 proteins implicated by these screens remain incompletely understood. Here, utilizing HCoV-341 OC43 as a model HCoV, we employed a genome-wide loss-of-function CRISPR screen to 342 identify and characterize factors required for efficient CoV infection. In particular, we show that 343 the retromer subunit protein VPS29 is required for productive infection by diverse CoVs in a 344 variety of cell types. Other genome-wide screens using SARS-CoV-2 have also suggested a role 345
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: for VPS29 and the CCC as well as RAB7A, which recruits retromer to endosomes ( in C, as well as the additional representative images in Supplemental Figure S5 ). 498
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: 10% represented guides to the bottom 10% represented guides was 3.94, well below the 567 recommended cutoff of 10 for an "ideal" library (Joung et al., 2017) ). To generate lentiviral 568 preparations of the Brunello library, 293T cells (6 x 10 6 cells per 10 cm dish) were transfected 569 with 6µg lentiCRISPRv2-Brunello, 6µg NL-gagpol, and 1.2 µg VSV-G using PEI. 48 hours post 570 transfection, supernatants were pooled and concentrated using Amicon Ultra Centrifugal Filters. 571
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

body_text.text: Concentrated lentiviral preps were stored at -80°C and titrated on A549 cells based on 572 puromycin resistance. Briefly, 10-fold serial dilutions (from 10 -1 to 10 -6 ) were used to transduce 573 40,000 A549 cells in a 24 well plate format. 48 hours post transduction, cells were trypsinized 574 and moved up to 6 well plates in the presence of 1.25 µg/mL puromycin. 9 days post 575 transduction, cells were fixed, stained with Crystal Violet, and stained foci were counted to 576 measure the number of cells surviving selection (i.e. those that were transduced with 577 lentiCRISPRv2 harboring a puromycin resistance cassette). To perform the screen, 1.3 x 10 8 578 A549 cells were transduced with lentiCRISPRv2-Brunello at an MOI of 0.3 in order to generate 579 a population of single KO cells at high (>500X) coverage. Two days post transduction, cells 580

body_text.text: were placed in selection with 1.25 µg/mL puromycin and passaged for 7 days, until there were 581 no untransduced cells remaining. Thereafter, in triplicates with 8x10 6 cells per flask, A549-582
body_text.section: Impairment of CoV and ebolavirus infection in VPS29 KO cells due to loss of endosomal 284

Subsequently, genes were annotated with UniProt keywords (https://uniprot.org) 596 597

FIGREF0.text: 2H-T). Since these viruses all rely on endocytic pathways for viral entry (Krzyzaniak et 148 al., 2013; Lakadamyali et al., 2004; Meier and Greber, 2004), these data indicate that 149 VPS29/CCC and WDR81/91 are specifically required for coronavirus infection, rather than 150 broadly impairing endocytic function. The magnitude of the effect of CCC complex and 151 WDR81/91 knockout on CoV infection was different in different cell lines. For example, KO of 152 the CCC complex or WDR81/91 had a blunted effect on CoV infection in HT1080-ACE2 cells 153 (Figure 2H-K). Moreover, in 293T-ACE2 cells, KO of the CCC complex inhibited HCoV-OC43 154 but not HCoV-NL63 or rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 infection, while WDR81/91 knockout impaired 155 infection for all three viruses (Figure 2O-Q). 156 157

FIGREF1.text: A CRISPR screen reveals genes influencing HCoV-OC43 susceptibility 425 (A) Schematic of screening setup (B) Screen results, where the x-axis corresponds to each 426unique gene in the library (labeled randomly from 1 to 19,114) and the y-axis denotes the -log10 427MAGeCK gene score. All genes scoring higher than the best-scoring non-targeting control 428 pseudogene are labeled in blue. The screen was performed in three independent replicates (C) 429string-db analysis and UniProt annotation of gene hits. Sphere colors correspond to UniProt430 keywords and connecting lines indicate strength of evidence underlying gene-gene interactions 431 (pink: experimentally-determined interaction; blue: annotated interaction in curated databases; 432 gray: evidence of co-expression; yellow: text-mining). 433 Requirement for identified host proteins is cell type and virus dependent 436 (A-X) Cells were infected with the indicated viruses at an MOI of 0.3. At 24 hours post 437 infection, cells were stained, and the percent infected cells was determined by flow cytometry. 438 (A-G): A549-ACE2, (H-N, U, W-X): HT1080-ACE2, (O-T): 293T-ACE2, (V): NHBE. TABREF1.text: WASH complex, which facilitates formation of actin patches on endosomes, 198 interacts with and is critical for some protein-sorting functions of retromer (Seaman et al., 2013). 199 RAB21 is a known effector of the WASH complex (Del Olmo et al., 2019). These data thus 200 suggest that the enhancement of IAV infection in VPS29 KO cells is due to the absence of an 201 intact Retromer/WASH complex. While KO or KD of VPS29 facilitates IAV infection, KD of 202 some VPS29-interacting proteins impaired IAV infection. For example, KD of SNX6 impaired To elucidate the impact of VPS29 on viral infection we next investigated the impact of VPS29 225KO on normal endosomal function. We labeled endosomes in living cells using a construct

TABREF2.text: Daniloski et 346 al., 2020; Hoffmann et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2021) in HCoV infection 347 348 While previous studies have hypothesized that the mechanism whereby VPS29/CCC complex 349 facilitates SARS-CoV-2 infection is by maintaining cell surface expression of viral receptors 350 (Daniloski et al., 2020; Zhu et al., 2021), our findings indicate a different role. Indeed, infection 351 by HCoVs that use three distinct receptors was inhibited by VPS29/CCC KO, while there was no 352 VPS29/CCC requirement for infection by IAV, adenovirus, or RSV-which should otherwise 353 also be dependent on cell-surface expression of their respective receptors. Indeed, HCoV-354 OC43's purported receptor (9-O-acetylated sialic acid) is nearly identical to IAV's receptor 355 (sialic acid). Yet, while HCoV-OC43 infection is highly dependent on VPS29/CCC, IAV 356 infection is either unaffected by these factors (in A549 cells) or hindered by them (in HT1080 357 and 293T cells). 358 359 A possible mechanism that might account for the enhancing effect VPS29 deficiency on IAV 360 infection could be retromer-dependent trafficking of endosomal cargo that antagonizes IAV 361 infection. While this notion is consistent with our finding that showing incoming IAV 362 accumulated in endosomes to a greater extent in normal than in VPS29 KO cells, the proteins 363 that might be responsible for mediating this effect are unknown. Other possibilities, include 364 direct influence of retromer on IAV containing endosomes, In this regard, retromer dependent 365 movement of human papilloma virus (HPV) to the TGN has been reported to involve direct 366 interaction between retromer and the HPV L2 protein (Popa et al., 2015). While loss of 367 retromer/WASH complex facilitated IAV infection in HT1080 cells, loss of other retromer-368 interacting proteins, such as SNX6 and Rab38, impaired IAV infection. Thus, distinct effector 369 functions of VPS29 may have different infection enhancing and inhibiting properties, with the 370 overall effect depending on viral and/or cell-type specific characteristics. Differences in 371 expression and/or activity of various VPS29 effector proteins may explain why VPS29 KO 372 facilitates IAV infection in HT1080 and 293T cells, but not in A549 cells. 373 374 However, VPS29 KO impaired CoV infection in all cells tested, including primary lung cells. 375 Nevertheless, we did observe some differences. Specifically, loss of both retromer and retriever 376 impaired HCoV-OC43 infection, while loss of retriever did not impair HCoV-NL63 or HCoV-377 229E or rVSV/SARS-CoV-2 infection. These findings suggest that there may be multiple roles 378 for VPS29 in HCoV infection, with some CoVs requiring the effector functions of distinct 379 VPS29-containing complexes. The precise requirement for distinct VPS29 functions could vary 380 with cell type, for example there was a decreased requirement for the CCC complex in HT1080 381 and 293T cells. Our finding that SARS-CoV-2R683G , SARS-CoV, and bat/pangolin CoVs were 382 all heavily impacted by both VPS29 KO and cathepsin inhibition suggests that these viruses are 383 especially sensitive to endocytic function, in line with recent work demonstrating that mutation 384 of the SARS-CoV-2 polybasic cleavage site drives virions to enter via the endocytic route 385 (Winstone et al., 2021). 386 387Based on our findings, it appears that a key feature of VPS29/retromer KO cells, is elevation of 388 the pH of endolysosomal compartments. This change should impair activation of cathepsins 389(Jerala et al., 1998), thus impeding endosomal CoV spike as well as EBOV GP processing and 390 egress from endosomes to initiate productive infection, consistent with our observations of

Sapiens; sex: female), A549 (H. Sapiens; sex: male), HT1080 (H. Sapiens; sex: 537 male), MDCK (Canis familiaris) and Vero cells (Cercopithecus aethiops) were obtained from 538 ATCC, and Huh7.5 cells (generously provided by Charles M. Rice) were maintained at 37°C and 539 5% CO2 in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Gibco) supplemented with 10% fetal 540 bovine serum. NHBE cells (H. Sapiens) were obtained from ATCC (Cat# ATCC PCS-300-010) 541 and maintained at 37°C and 5% CO2 in Airway Epithelial Cell Basal Medium (ATCC PCS-300-542 030) supplemented with Bronchial Epithelial Cell Growth Kit (ATCC PCS-300-040). All cells 543 have been assessed for Mycoplasma contamination.544 545 Production of viral stocks 546 HCoV-OC43 (strain: ATCC VR-759) and HCoV-229E (strain: ATCC VR-740) were obtained 547 from Zeptometrix Corporation, and HCoV-NL63 (strain: Amsterdam I) was obtained from the 548 Biodefense and Emerging Infections Research Resources Repository. Viral stocks were 549 generated by propagation on Huh7.5 cells. The IAV strains A/WSN/33 (H1N1), 550 A/Netherlands/602/2009 (H1N1)pdm09 (H1N12009 Netherlands), A/California/04/2009 551 (H1N1)pdm09 (H1N12009 California) were propagated in MDCK cells. RSV strain A2-line19F 552 expressing the red fluorescent protein monomeric Katushka 2 (mKate2;(Hotard et al., 2012)) was 553 propagated in Vero cells. Adenovirus 5 was purchased from ATCC (VR-1516) and propagated in 554 A549 cells. VSVIND(eGFP) was propagated on 293T cells (Whelan et al., 2000). The replication-555 competent chimeric recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus encoding SARS-CoV-2 S and green 556 fluorescent protein (eGFP), rVSV/SARS-2/GFP2E1, has been described previously (Schmidt et 557 al., 2020) and was propagated on 293T-ACE2 cells. rVSV/EBOV-GP was propagated on Vero 558 cells as previously described (Mulherkar et al., 2011). The human genome-wide Brunello Library (Doench et al., 2016) in lentiCRISPRv2 was obtained 563from Addgene (cat# 73179) and amplified according to depositor's instructions. Resulting 564 plasmid DNA was validated via NGS sequencing to confirm appropriate coverage and 565

TABREF4.text: 1, and passaged for 7 days 583 until >95% infection-induced cell death occurred. Cellular gDNA was isolated using Zymogen 584 Quick-DNA Midiprep Plus Kit (Zymo Research), and sequencing libraries prepared via 585 amplication of sgRNA loci utilizing F primers containing P5 and Read 1 Sequencing Primer and 586 a R primer containing P7, a barcode, and the multiplexing Index Read Sequencing Primer, as 587 described in Joung et al, 2017. Resulting libraries were gel purified, pooled, and sequenced on 588 the Illumina HiSeq at Genewiz using 80 cycles of Read 1 (Forward) and 8 Cycles of Index 1 589 using standard Illumina sequencing primers. 590 591

back_matter.text: lentiCRISPRv2, which does not harbor an sgRNA cassette, was used. Lentiviral preparations 607were obtained by transfecting 1x10 6 293Ts with 1µg lentiCRISPRv2, 1µg NL-gagpol, and .2µg 608 VSV-G using PEI. 2 days post transfection, supernatants were collected, filtered, and used to 609 transduce 5x10 4 A549-ACE2, HT1080-ACE2, 293T-ACE2, or NHBE cells. 2 days post 610 transduction, cells were trypsinized, placed in selection with 1.25µg/mL puromycin, and 611passaged until there were no remaining viable untransduced cells. CRISPR Raw FASTQ files were aligned to the Brunello library and scored using the MAGeCK statistical 782package. All flow cytometry data were analyzed using FlowJo software, version 10.6.1. All 783 graphs were generated using GraphPad Prism, version 8. Error bars correspond to the standard 784 deviation. All images were generated by maximum intensity projection using Fiji (https://fiji.sc/).
